name: BRAIN TUMOR/INF
indications: Indicated for the detection, characterization, and follow-up of brain tumors or suspected infections. Contrast helps to visualize abnormal tissue and inflammation.
contrast_rationale: Tumors and areas of infection often disrupt the blood-brain barrier, causing contrast to accumulate and 'enhance'. This helps delineate tumor margins, distinguish abscesses from solid masses, and assess for disease activity.

name: BRAIN MS
indications: Specifically designed to detect and monitor the characteristic lesions of Multiple Sclerosis. Contrast is used to identify active areas of inflammation.
contrast_rationale: In Multiple Sclerosis, active inflammation causes a temporary breakdown of the blood-brain barrier. Enhancing lesions indicate active disease, helping to distinguish new from old plaques and monitor treatment effectiveness.

contrast_rationale: Contrast is essential for visualizing small tumors like acoustic neuromas (vestibular schwannomas), which enhance avidly. It helps to precisely define the size and extent of the tumor.

name: PITUITARY
indications: For evaluating pituitary gland abnormalities, such as adenomas, often related to hormonal imbalances. Dynamic contrast helps differentiate small tumors from normal gland tissue.
contrast_rationale: The normal pituitary gland enhances rapidly, while adenomas enhance more slowly. Dynamic imaging captures this difference, making even small microadenomas visible against the intensely enhancing normal gland.
